Literature Review: Asthma is a complex and multifactorial disease that has been challenging to treat despite the development of sophisticated biologics. The persistence of symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, and coughing in patients following treatment suggests that there may be an underlying factor contributing to the disease. Recent studies have highlighted the role of mucus plugs in obstructing the airways and perpetuating inflammation, which may be an overlooked but critical feature of asthmatic airway disease. This review aims to examine the evidence that mucus plugs contribute to a substantial portion of disease and explore the alterations in mucus biology driven by type 2 inflammation. We will also discuss the potential mechanisms by which mucus plugs may act as an immunogenic stimulus and contribute to exacerbations. Mucus plugs are a common feature of asthma, and their presence has been observed in both children and adults. These plugs are composed of mucus, dead cells, and other debris that accumulate in the airways and can physically obstruct airflow. In addition to their mechanical effects, mucus plugs can also perpetuate inflammation by providing a platform for the colonization of viruses, bacteria, and fungi. This can lead to exacerbations of the disease, which are a major concern for patients with asthma. The alterations in mucus biology driven by type 2 inflammation are a key factor in the development of mucus plugs. Type 2 inflammation is characterized by the production of cytokines such as IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13, which promote the production of IgE and the activation of eosinophils. These cells contribute to the production of mucus and the formation of mucus plugs. Furthermore, the presence of galectin-10, a lectin that binds to galectin-3, has been shown to play a critical role in the formation of mucus plugs. Galectin-10 promotes the aggregation of neutrophils, which are a key component of the inflammatory response in asthma. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell that plays a critical role in the inflammatory response in asthma. They are activated by cytokines such as IL-17 and TNF-alpha, which promote their migration to the airways. Once activated, neutrophils release granules that contain enzymes and antimicrobial peptides, which can contribute to the destruction of mucus plugs and the clearance of pathogens. However, in the absence of effective clearance mechanisms, neutrophils can also contribute to the perpetuation of inflammation and the formation of mucus plugs. The role of mucus plugs in asthma has been highlighted by several studies. A study published in the Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology found that patients with asthma who had a higher concentration of mucus plugs in their sputum had a greater risk of exacerbations. Another study published in the European Respiratory Journal found that the use of corticosteroids was associated with a reduction in mucus plug formation and a decrease in symptoms. In addition to their role in obstructing airflow and perpetuating inflammation, mucus plugs may also act as an immunogenic stimulus. This can occur through the release of antigens from dead cells and other debris that accumulate in the mucus plugs. These antigens can stimulate an immune response, which can contribute to the development of asthma. Furthermore, the presence of mucus plugs can also contribute to the development of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), a condition characterized by airflow limitation and inflammation. In conclusion, mucus plugs are a critical feature of asthmatic airway disease. They can physically obstruct airflow and perpetuate inflammation, and may also act as an immunogenic stimulus. The alterations in mucus biology driven by type 2 inflammation are a key factor in the development of mucus plugs, and the role of neutrophils in the inflammatory response is also critical. Further research is needed to fully understand the mechanisms by which mucus plugs contribute to asthma and to develop effective treatments for this complex disease.
